newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: PRESS DIGEST-Australian Business News - April 30.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST-Australian Business News - April 30.

text.p: (Compiled for Reuters by Media Monitors)
THE AUSTRALIAN FINANCIAL REVIEW

In the biggest shake-up since BHP, the Federal Government, and the unions developed the Steel Plan in 1983, BHP announced yesterday it would be closing its Newcastle steelworks in 1999 and warned that two smaller mills in Sydney and Geelong would also be closed down as part of the company's plan to become internationally competitive by the year 2000. Page 1.

In preparation for an expected takeover bid from media magnate Kerry Packer, Brierley Investments Ltd, which controls the John Fairfax newspaper group, is looking into plans to establish an Australian company to take on its Fairfax holdings in order to get around foreign ownership limits which stop it increasing its stake. Page 1.

Releasing the 1997-98 Victorian Budget yesterday, State Treasurer Alan Stockdale announced payroll taxes for business will be cut by A$103 million, from seven per cent to 6.25 per cent, in a move which means most of the 15,000 Victorian employers paying the tax would pay less. Page 1.

Seven Network shares rose by 19 cents yesterday to close at a record A$4.80 following the announcement that the broadcast giant and United States entrepreneur Kirk Kerkorian plan to bring forward the A$3 billion public float of Hollywood's MGM studios, whch was beefed up for the listing through the purchase of Orion Pictures, announced yesterday. Page 21.

National Australia Bank's A$200 million-plus bid for A$18 billion funds manager Axiom Funds Management became embroiled in controversy yesterday when it was revealed that Michael Lambert, the former head of the New South Wales Treasury, has been offering advice on the bank's bid as part of his current advisory position at BZW. Page 21.

The embattled Reef Casino Trust has received its first solid proposal to solve its financial woes since January, when the casino was forced by its bankers to seek an equity injection of up to A$50 million to lower its A$105 million debt. The Australian Torism Group yesterday proposed bringing in a Malaysian casino owner, the Sinophil Corp, to provide a major capital injection. Page 21.
THE AUSTRALIAN

The restructuring of BHP Steel, which will see the closure of its Newcastle steelworks and other downstream operations and will result in the loss of 3,000 jobs, triggered a fundamental re-rating of BHP on the Australian Stock Exchange yesterday, adding amost A$1 billion to the market value of the nation's largest company. Page 21.

Publishing & Broadcasting, which is 45 per cent owned by Kerry Packer's privately owned Consolidated Press Holdings, is preparing to withdraw its A$342 million offer to buy control of the Sydney casino SHC.AX at a time when the company is planning to nearly double its size with its looming takeover bid for John Fairfax Holdings Ltd. Page 21.

Hollywood studio Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, which is half-owned by Seven Network Ltd, is to float within 18 months following yesterday's A$736 million acquisition of entertainment assets from Metromedia International - a deal Seven chairman Kerry Stokes says wil bring more than US$50 million of annual revenue into MGM. Page 21.

After a year's absence from Australia, Minorco, the international division of the South African-based Anglo American Corp, has re-emerged with a 10 per cent holding in junior gold explorer Goldstream Mining NL, which has the largest fully diluted ground holding in South Australia's prospective Gawler Craton region. Page 23.

Gold miner St Barbara Mines Ltd announced yesterday it has withdrawn its all-scrip bid of 32 shares for every 10 Mount Leyshon Gold Mines shares was no longer available, but offered no reason for the decision. The announcement was made on the eve of the bid's scheduled close. Page 23.

EchoStar revealed yesterday the News Corp has indicated it could withdraw its proposed A$1.3 billion investment in the United States satellite-TV operator unless EchoStar agrees to use News' security card system to unscramble satellite signals. The threat to the proposed alliance comes just days ahead of a deadline to finalise the deal. Page 23.
THE SYDNEY MORNING HERALD

Following the release yesterday of a major review of BHP's position in the steel industry which recommended low-return operations should be closed and the group's Australasian steelmaking facilities be consolidated, BHP Steel chief executive officer Ron McNeilly said the division would be pushing for cost savings far beyond its previous target of A$500 million a year. Page 27.

In contrast to earlier plans to add front-end steel making facilities to BHP Steel's Asian plants in order to capture a larger share of the expanding market, division chief executive officer Ron McNeilly said yesterday the group's network of rolling plants across Asia would be free to source steel from the most competitive suppliers. Page 27.

Following the announcement of its major steel restructuring plan, stockbroking analysts are predicting BHP will quit its 36.5 per cent stake in the Foster's Brewing Group, with stockbrokers Merrill Lynch and SBC Warburg tipped to be the leading contenders to sell the bulk of the stake to institutions. Page 27.

The Seven Network and United States billionaire Kirk Kerkorian are planning a A$405 million float of their Hollywood film studio Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Inc for next year following the A$767 million purchase of the Metromedia International Group from media baron John Kluge - a deal that adds 2,200 film titles to MGM's existing library of 1,500, making it the largest in the world. Page 27.

The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission is to examine whether Colonial CGH.AX breached section 52 of the Corporations Law when it shut its public share offer four days early. The company did not issue a statement in its prospectus saying directors reserved the right to close the offer early and many retailers are complaining the move was unfair. Page 29.

Speaking at Sydney Harbour Casino's annual meeting yesterday, chairman Dick Warburton revealed the casino lost A$600,000 in its first quarter after writing off large pre-opening costs on its permanent casino site. Operating profit before abnormal items an tax jumped 10 per cent to A$18.6 million in the three months to March this year. Page 29.
THE AGE

Under a radical overhaul expected to save BHP well over A$500 million, the Big Australian has announced it will close its Newcastle steelmaking plant by 1999 and is also considering the future of Whyalla, New Zealand Steel, and the hot-strip rolling facilties at Westernport and in New Zealand. Page 1.

The share price of the Seven Network rose 19 cents yesterday to close at a record A$4.80 after Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, its joint Hollywood studio venture, announced it had paid US$573 million in cash and debt to buy Metromedia International - a deal that wil give MGM Metromedia's library of 2,200 film and TV titles. Page 1.

Speaking at the group's annual meeting in the Papua New Guinean capital of Port Moresby yesterday, the chairman of RTZ-CRA unit Bougainville Copper Ltd, David Karpin, said the company had no knowledge of the Government's aborted plan to use mercenaries to resolve the conflict on Bougainville. Page B2.

The Residual Assco Group - formerly Adelaide Steamship Co - is to raise $A160 million through the float of its 122-year-old Adsteam Marine. Adsteam is set to become an aggressive player in the towage industry, and with the prospectus registered yesterday ith the Australian Securities Commission, 80 million shares are to be offered at $A2 each. Page B2.

The restructuring of BHP's operations saw shares rise strongly yesterday both in response to the move and on the back of a resurgent Wall Street. Inspired by a strong futures market the All Ordinaries closed 17.4 points higher at 2479.1, with the June conract on the Share Price Index also finishing at a seven-point premium to the physical at 2486. Page B2.

Australia's biggest grocery wholesaler Davids warned yesterday that as a partial result of weak trading, its profit after abnormals for the June financial year would fall below the previous year's level. Triggered by the announcement was a 6 per cent drop in Davids' share price to an 18-month low of $A1.26. Page B3.
-- Reuters Sydney Newsroom 61-2 9373-1800
